Y. M. C. A. Meetings.

Gaseous Information.

The cry is now for individual
drinking cups. In Queen Elizabeth's time every guest at a banquet
brought his own spoon with him.
A cubic foot of newly fallen
snow weighs five and a half pounds
and has twelve times the bulk of an
equal weight of water.

Monday and Tuesday of last
week the University Y. M. C. A.
held its special yearly meeting in
the chapel. As the meetings occurred the week the Men and Re- •
ligion Movement's team was in Baltimore, Mr. Holmes was able to
procure as speakers Rev. Charles
Stelzle, the leader of the 'team,"
and R. A. Waite, Jr., the specialist
in boys' work.
Mr. Waite, who is a graduate of
Syracuse, spoke at 1.20 P. M., Monday. He delivered a very strong
message on "What Are You Worth
in the World's Market ?" Mr.
Waite, prior to his connection with
the Men and Religion Movement,
was international secretary of the
Y. AI. C. A.
Rev. Charles Stelzle is the man
who has been so actively engaged
in the work of the Labor Temple
in New York. He spoke Tuesday
mid-day on "Social Service," showing both the great need and the
equally great opportunities for
strong young men in this sort of
activity.
The Rev. Harris It. Kirk, of Baltimore, had charge of the afternoon
meetings on both days.

THE NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 5, 1912.
VARSITY BASEBALL STARTED
Plenty of Good Material From Which
to Select Team List of Games
Is Announced.

The organization meeting of the
'Varsity baseball team did a great
deal to boom the sport at the University. Some sixty students were
Present in the Trophy Room, where
the meeting was held—a great many
of these being freshmen. Captain
Pieper opened the meeting with a
short speech, and introduced Mr.
Harlan, the coach. He urged the
men who would try for the team
to assume the right attitude toward
the manner of coaching, and hoped
that no candidate would take his corrections personally. He announced
the first practice for Wednesday of
this week, at 2.15; the second for
Saturday, at 1.30.
Dr. Roulston was the next speaker. He dispelled the impression
that he had been made an adviser of
the team because he had been a
one-time "star," which he thought
had its birth in the mind of some
enterprising reporter. In his day
there were nine at the organization
meeting, who elected a captain, and
Who, in turn, set a day for the first
Practice. Four candidates appeared
on that day, the captain not among
them, who, it was found out, was
Playing golf'. The second practice
With a different set of four men
present was the end of his career
as the star player he has credit of
having been.
Lynn Meekins concluded the talking with an interesting account of
the coming season. The following
list of games is complete:
March 30—Catholic University
at Washington.
April 4—Princeton at Homewood.
April 8—Yale at Homewood.
April 13—Harvard at Homewood.
April 20—Georgetown at Washington.

WAGONS

Oh, the big bandwagon, where the
music plays
And the candidates assemble with
their songs of praise:
Where they shout till midnight and
they start at dawn—
Just wait a minute, driver, till we
all climb on!
Oh, the water wagon, with its style
so neat!
Room for everybody on a nice front
seat,
Where we all feel thankful 'cause
the headache's gone—
Wait a minute, driver, till we all
climb on!
But this old ice wagon that is trying to keep
The road blockaded where the snow
piles deep
While the north wind's blowin' with
a wheeze and a cough—
Hoist the warm wave signal till we
all get off!
—Washington Star.
Delegate Campbell's Bill.

Delegate Thomas G. Campbell,
A. B. '05, the sponsor for the Equal
Suffrage Bill, has introduced an
Act to propose a new constitutional
amendment for the restriction of
the suffrage of the ignorant. Mr.
Campbell lays great stress on the
fact that the proposed amendment
will not in the least interfere with
the rights of men now voting; the
simple purpose of the amendment
is to improve the intelligence of
the electorate. If this amendment
should pass, one weighty argument
against equal suffrage—that negro
women should have equal political
rights with white women—would
be considerably less weighty.

Cr. Nitobe's Lectures.

Monday last, Dr. Nitobe presented in the concert hall of the
Academy of Music, his sixth lecture
on Japan. His topic for that afternoon was "Moral Ideals and Morals." The inclement weather did
not diminish the usual large attendance.
Dr. Nitobe denied that the Japanese are people who are immoral
or have no fixed ideals.
"A feeling of great patriotism
characterizes our people," he said.
Dr. Nitobe has frequently spoken
his lectures of the devotion of the
Japanese to their Emperor. Monday he said: "The love for the
Emperor is one of the characteristics of our life." According to the
lecturer, the Japanese have as much
paternal affection as Americans, but
that they have also filial affection,
and consider the rights of the son,
as well as the rights ,of the parents.
On Thursday, Dr. Nitobe illustrated his lecture with lantern slides.
He also spoke extemporaneously,
forsaking his manuscript. He said
that Japan is largely mountainous,
only about 13 per cent. being under
cultivation, yet 60 per cent, of the
inhabitants are engaged in agricultural pursuits.
The American popular idea is
that the Japanese eat rice as their
main article of food. Dr. Nitobe
stated that this is erroneous. He
said that the poorer people do not
eat rice, because it costs too much.
The people who do eat rice always
accompany such a diet with beans.
The Japanese also have an immense
radish, which forms an important
part of the food supply.
"There are few millionaires in
Japan," he concluded, "for we are
a poor nation."

Co-eds'Cozy Corner
A Real One From a Live One.

FEBRUARY 2, 1912.
To

the Editor of TM:, NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Editor—I have been worrying for some moments how to address you. Now, my "Read's Rapid
Ready Writer" says "'Dear Sir' has
acquired a business signification."
So I did not want to use it as I
was afraid you would tear it into
smithereens without even seeing
that it was from me and not a bill
from the new book department, or
an epistle from your adviser. But
yet I was afraid you might think it
unmaidenly if I called you just dear.
But perhaps I want to be formal
as I am very angry with you.
I think you have been perfectly
horrid, and all the other girls think
so, too. When I first saw you were
going to have a co-eds' column,
I thought why how perfectly lovely,
and how ridiculous it will be to
hear the boys discuss the fashions,
saying that there will be a marked
tendency to long scamps or that
long hatpins and jabots will be in
evidence. And then, too, I thought
I can find out what color dresses
the boys like best. You know I hate
to come to the dynamics class and
feel that nobody likes my dress.
Now, for instance, I don't know
what to wear to the cotillon on
Friday. I left my pink marquisette
home and I can't wear my violet,
as I just know he won't buy any
for me to wear with it.
Oh, yes, I remember I was saying how angry all the girls are.

I

You Should Come
TO THE

Cotillon Club's Dance

thought that in the Cozy Corner you
were going to take up the cudgels
in behalf of down-trodden womanhood, and show how glorious it
would be if women would have one
rein of the ship of state; and the
lowly factory worker, relieved of the
burden of taxes and toil, amid the
last rays of the sun setting in glory,
should rise to work no more. Oh!
isn't this fine! I'm going to make
this the last sentence of a thesis
I am writing, called "Warring Woman Wants World." Please publish it, won't you, when I finish it?
Now I must begin to study again.
At dollege you could always find
someone to make fudge for, when
your head began to ache; but here
nobody seems to care for marshmallow fudge. Good-bye,
BESSY B.
Knew What to Treat Her For.

Dr. Simon G. Ruthven, the distinguished ophthalmologist, was asked
about a certain sensational medical
discovery.
It all seems about as likely to
me," said Dr. Ruthven, "as the case
of the Pennsylvania student.
"A Pennsylvania student, hurrying out Powelton avenue, was
stopped by a friend.
"'What's your hurry?' asked the
friend. 'A good case?'
"'A good case? Rather!' said
the student. 'We've got in the
ophthalmological ward a woman so
cross-eyed that the tears run down
her back.'
"'Dear me!' said the other. 'You
can't do anything for her, can you?'
"'Of course we can,' the student
answered. 'We are treating her for
bacteria.'"—V': York Sun.

Our old rival, St. John's, has
enough gumption to get out a yearbook—The Rat-Tat. Is the Johns
Hopkins to rank above other universities merely in learning, and
fall sadly "below par" in college
activities?
A whisker-growing contest is being held at the University of Colorado. The swain who succeeds in
growing the most beautiful hirsute
adornment will have his picture officially published in the Silver and
Gold, the University weekly.

Eleven Syracuse University men
were suspended by Chancellor Day
after they admitted having been
given questions to be asked in history examination in advance of the
examinations. Twenty-four out of
fifty history students handed in
papers drawing a mark of 100 per
cent. This led to an investigation.
It is thought that they were stolen
from a bundle left by a printer at
the students' supply store. No such
chance at Hopkins, where the questions are typewritten, and in some
cases in long hand.

FEBRUARY 1, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—Possibly you. can enlighten me about a matter concerning which I am slightly curious.
Why does the COtillon Club, by its
advertisement in THE NEws-LETTER, invite anyone in the University to attend the dances it gives,
When . the members of the Board
know that it is practically impossible for anyone, not belonging to
a fraternity, to get anyone to exchange dances with him, owing to
the fact that three or four of the
largest fraternities refuse to exchange dances with anyone not belonging to their own crowd? If it.
IS to be a fraternity dance, why
don't they say so, and not . invite
everyone? Also, as a matter of
curiosity, why is the Cotillon Board
made up of One man from each
fraternity? I would really apprecite any information about this matter.
CURIOUS.
January II, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

In your issue of last week there
was offered the suggestion that the
names of men elected to the various
fraternities be published in the
columns of THE NEWS-LETM.
The suggestion must be entirely
well meant, nor has there been for
a long time the slightest trace of
any anti-fraternity feeling at Hopkins; yet, does not the suggestion
contain a germ which might prove
dangerous? Would not the publication of the pines of men elected
to the fraternities seem to confer
a certain sort of distinction upon
those men? Would it not cause
election to a fraternity to come to
be considered in the light of an
honor? Would it not tend to alter
the character of fraternities from
Private groups of congenial spirits
to public organizations? Under
existing conditions it is no particular distinction to belong to a fraternity—to be a friend of Will
Smith and his set, or of Jim Jones
and his set. It is no particular disgrace not to belong to such an
organization. Yet, should fraternities, by means of publicity, be
dragged into the limelight—should
the fact that John Roe has joined
this crowd, or Harry Lee that
crowd, come to be considered a
matter of sufficient importance to
deserve public notice—then there
could hardly fail to arise a feeling
that these fraternities are very
fine things and that it is a disgrace not 'to belong to one of

them; and the appearance of such
a feeling would mark the appearance of snobbishness and the disappearance of that democratic
spirit which on the whole has thus
far characterized the student life
at Hopkins.

Cautious College Socialists.

In order that the students who
desire to study Socialism, but who
are unwilling to enroll themselves
as Socialists, may be Socialists in
spirit, if not in name, the Socialists at Columbia University have
changed the name of their undergraduate organization from the Columbia University Socialist Society
to the Society for the Study of
Socialism. The first meeting under
the new name was better attended
than any of the previous meetings
of the club. The club is composed
of about thirty students and several
members of The faculty who are
interested in Socialism.

Monday and Tuesday of last
week the University Y. M. C. A.
held its special yearly meeting in
the chapel. As the meetings occurred the week the Men and Re- •
ligion Movement's team was in Baltimore, Mr. Holmes was able to
procure as speakers Rev. Charles
Stelzle, the leader of the 'team,"
and R. A. Waite, Jr., the specialist
in boys' work.
Mr. Waite, who is a graduate of
Syracuse, spoke at 1.20 P. M., Monday. He delivered a very strong
message on "What Are You Worth
in the World's Market ?" Mr.
Waite, prior to his connection with
the Men and Religion Movement,
was international secretary of the
Y. AI. C. A.
Rev. Charles Stelzle is the man
who has been so actively engaged
in the work of the Labor Temple
in New York. He spoke Tuesday
mid-day on "Social Service," showing both the great need and the
equally great opportunities for
strong young men in this sort of
activity.
The Rev. Harris It. Kirk, of Baltimore, had charge of the afternoon
meetings on both days.

THE NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 5, 1912.
VARSITY BASEBALL STARTED
Plenty of Good Material From Which
to Select Team List of Games
Is Announced.

The organization meeting of the
'Varsity baseball team did a great
deal to boom the sport at the University. Some sixty students were
Present in the Trophy Room, where
the meeting was held—a great many
of these being freshmen. Captain
Pieper opened the meeting with a
short speech, and introduced Mr.
Harlan, the coach. He urged the
men who would try for the team
to assume the right attitude toward
the manner of coaching, and hoped
that no candidate would take his corrections personally. He announced
the first practice for Wednesday of
this week, at 2.15; the second for
Saturday, at 1.30.
Dr. Roulston was the next speaker. He dispelled the impression
that he had been made an adviser of
the team because he had been a
one-time "star," which he thought
had its birth in the mind of some
enterprising reporter. In his day
there were nine at the organization
meeting, who elected a captain, and
Who, in turn, set a day for the first
Practice. Four candidates appeared
on that day, the captain not among
them, who, it was found out, was
Playing golf'. The second practice
With a different set of four men
present was the end of his career
as the star player he has credit of
having been.
Lynn Meekins concluded the talking with an interesting account of
the coming season. The following
list of games is complete:
March 30—Catholic University
at Washington.
April 4—Princeton at Homewood.
April 8—Yale at Homewood.
April 13—Harvard at Homewood.
April 20—Georgetown at Washington.

Oh, the big bandwagon, where the
music plays
And the candidates assemble with
their songs of praise:
Where they shout till midnight and
they start at dawn—
Just wait a minute, driver, till we
all climb on!
Oh, the water wagon, with its style
so neat!
Room for everybody on a nice front
seat,
Where we all feel thankful 'cause
the headache's gone—
Wait a minute, driver, till we all
climb on!
But this old ice wagon that is trying to keep
The road blockaded where the snow
piles deep
While the north wind's blowin' with
a wheeze and a cough—
Hoist the warm wave signal till we
all get off!
—Washington Star.
Delegate Campbell's Bill.

Delegate Thomas G. Campbell,
A. B. '05, the sponsor for the Equal
Suffrage Bill, has introduced an
Act to propose a new constitutional
amendment for the restriction of
the suffrage of the ignorant. Mr.
Campbell lays great stress on the
fact that the proposed amendment
will not in the least interfere with
the rights of men now voting; the
simple purpose of the amendment
is to improve the intelligence of
the electorate. If this amendment
should pass, one weighty argument
against equal suffrage—that negro
women should have equal political
rights with white women—would
be considerably less weighty.

Cr. Nitobe's Lectures.

Monday last, Dr. Nitobe presented in the concert hall of the
Academy of Music, his sixth lecture
on Japan. His topic for that afternoon was "Moral Ideals and Morals." The inclement weather did
not diminish the usual large attendance.
Dr. Nitobe denied that the Japanese are people who are immoral
or have no fixed ideals.
"A feeling of great patriotism
characterizes our people," he said.
Dr. Nitobe has frequently spoken
his lectures of the devotion of the
Japanese to their Emperor. Monday he said: "The love for the
Emperor is one of the characteristics of our life." According to the
lecturer, the Japanese have as much
paternal affection as Americans, but
that they have also filial affection,
and consider the rights of the son,
as well as the rights ,of the parents.
On Thursday, Dr. Nitobe illustrated his lecture with lantern slides.
He also spoke extemporaneously,
forsaking his manuscript. He said
that Japan is largely mountainous,
only about 13 per cent. being under
cultivation, yet 60 per cent, of the
inhabitants are engaged in agricultural pursuits.
The American popular idea is
that the Japanese eat rice as their
main article of food. Dr. Nitobe
stated that this is erroneous. He
said that the poorer people do not
eat rice, because it costs too much.
The people who do eat rice always
accompany such a diet with beans.
The Japanese also have an immense
radish, which forms an important
part of the food supply.
"There are few millionaires in
Japan," he concluded, "for we are
a poor nation."

FEBRUARY 2, 1912.
To

the Editor of TM:, NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Editor—I have been worrying for some moments how to address you. Now, my "Read's Rapid
Ready Writer" says "'Dear Sir' has
acquired a business signification."
So I did not want to use it as I
was afraid you would tear it into
smithereens without even seeing
that it was from me and not a bill
from the new book department, or
an epistle from your adviser. But
yet I was afraid you might think it
unmaidenly if I called you just dear.
But perhaps I want to be formal
as I am very angry with you.
I think you have been perfectly
horrid, and all the other girls think
so, too. When I first saw you were
going to have a co-eds' column,
I thought why how perfectly lovely,
and how ridiculous it will be to
hear the boys discuss the fashions,
saying that there will be a marked
tendency to long scamps or that
long hatpins and jabots will be in
evidence. And then, too, I thought
I can find out what color dresses
the boys like best. You know I hate
to come to the dynamics class and
feel that nobody likes my dress.
Now, for instance, I don't know
what to wear to the cotillon on
Friday. I left my pink marquisette
home and I can't wear my violet,
as I just know he won't buy any
for me to wear with it.
Oh, yes, I remember I was saying how angry all the girls are.

I

You Should Come
TO THE

Cotillon Club's Dance

thought that in the Cozy Corner you
were going to take up the cudgels
in behalf of down-trodden womanhood, and show how glorious it
would be if women would have one
rein of the ship of state; and the
lowly factory worker, relieved of the
burden of taxes and toil, amid the
last rays of the sun setting in glory,
should rise to work no more. Oh!
isn't this fine! I'm going to make
this the last sentence of a thesis
I am writing, called "Warring Woman Wants World." Please publish it, won't you, when I finish it?
Now I must begin to study again.
At dollege you could always find
someone to make fudge for, when
your head began to ache; but here
nobody seems to care for marshmallow fudge. Good-bye,

Knew What to Treat Her For.

Dr. Simon G. Ruthven, the distinguished ophthalmologist, was asked
about a certain sensational medical
discovery.
It all seems about as likely to
me," said Dr. Ruthven, "as the case
of the Pennsylvania student.
"A Pennsylvania student, hurrying out Powelton avenue, was
stopped by a friend.
"'What's your hurry?' asked the
friend. 'A good case?'
"'A good case? Rather!' said
the student. 'We've got in the
ophthalmological ward a woman so
cross-eyed that the tears run down
her back.'
"'Dear me!' said the other. 'You
can't do anything for her, can you?'
"'Of course we can,' the student
answered. 'We are treating her for
bacteria.'"—V': York Sun.

chance at Hopkins, where the questions are typewritten, and in some
cases in long hand.

FEBRUARY 1, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—Possibly you. can enlighten me about a matter concerning which I am slightly curious.
Why does the COtillon Club, by its
advertisement in THE NEws-LETTER, invite anyone in the University to attend the dances it gives,
When . the members of the Board
know that it is practically impossible for anyone, not belonging to
a fraternity, to get anyone to exchange dances with him, owing to
the fact that three or four of the
largest fraternities refuse to exchange dances with anyone not belonging to their own crowd? If it.
IS to be a fraternity dance, why
don't they say so, and not . invite
everyone? Also, as a matter of
curiosity, why is the Cotillon Board
made up of One man from each
fraternity? I would really apprecite any information about this matter.
CURIOUS.
January II, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

In your issue of last week there
was offered the suggestion that the
names of men elected to the various
fraternities be published in the
columns of THE NEWS-LETM.
The suggestion must be entirely
well meant, nor has there been for
a long time the slightest trace of
any anti-fraternity feeling at Hopkins; yet, does not the suggestion
contain a germ which might prove
dangerous? Would not the publication of the pines of men elected
to the fraternities seem to confer
a certain sort of distinction upon
those men? Would it not cause
election to a fraternity to come to
be considered in the light of an
honor? Would it not tend to alter
the character of fraternities from
Private groups of congenial spirits
to public organizations? Under
existing conditions it is no particular distinction to belong to a fraternity—to be a friend of Will
Smith and his set, or of Jim Jones
and his set. It is no particular disgrace not to belong to such an
organization. Yet, should fraternities, by means of publicity, be
dragged into the limelight—should
the fact that John Roe has joined
this crowd, or Harry Lee that
crowd, come to be considered a
matter of sufficient importance to
deserve public notice—then there
could hardly fail to arise a feeling
that these fraternities are very
fine things and that it is a disgrace not 'to belong to one of

them; and the appearance of such
a feeling would mark the appearance of snobbishness and the disappearance of that democratic
spirit which on the whole has thus
far characterized the student life
at Hopkins.

Cautious College Socialists.

In order that the students who
desire to study Socialism, but who
are unwilling to enroll themselves
as Socialists, may be Socialists in
spirit, if not in name, the Socialists at Columbia University have
changed the name of their undergraduate organization from the Columbia University Socialist Society
to the Society for the Study of
Socialism. The first meeting under
the new name was better attended
than any of the previous meetings
of the club. The club is composed
of about thirty students and several
members of The faculty who are
interested in Socialism.
